thread.title: For Kawhi Leonard, the goal is more championships nothing more
thread.title_full: For Kawhi Leonard, the goal is more championships nothing more - San Antonio Express-News

author: Jabari Young
title: For Kawhi Leonard, the goal is more championships nothing more

Photo: Kin Man Hui, Staff / San Antonio Express-News Spurs' Kawhi Leonard (02) acknowledges the crowd after receiving... Image 2 of 43 Kawhi Leonard facts
Kawhi Leonard facts Image 3 of 43 1. He is the youngest child and has four older sisters.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 1. He is the youngest child and has four older sisters. Image 4 of 43 2. He was born to Mike Leonard and Kim Robertson on June 29, 1991 in Los Angeles.
Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, San Antonio Express-News 2. He was born to Mike Leonard and Kim Robertson on June 29, 1991... Image 5 of 43 3. He looked something like this when Tim Duncan was drafted.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 3. He looked something like this when Tim Duncan was drafted. Image 6 of 43 4. He attended Martin Luther King High School in Los Angeles, California, and graduated in 2009. The same year, he earned the title of Mr. Basketball California.
Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, San Antonio Express-News 4. He attended Martin Luther King High School in Los Angeles,... Image 7 of 43 5. He drove the same ride he had in college, a Chevy Malibu, during his first year in the NBA then finally spoiled himself with a Porsche, after being pressured by his family and friends. "I don't have a car not on it. It's good on gas. It's a good commuter car [...]," he told the San Diego Union-Tribune.
5. He drove the same ride he had in college, a Chevy Malibu, during... Image 8 of 43 6. He's known for being reserved but somehow he's been able to make some pretty popular friends. Here he is with rapper Lil Wayne and his manager, Cortez Bryant, who is a mega Spurs fan.
6. He's known for being reserved but somehow he's been able to make... Image 9 of 43 7. He is the first Jordan Brand athlete to be named Finals MVP since Michael Jordan.
Photo: Dan McCarney 7. He is the first Jordan Brand athlete to be named Finals MVP... Image 10 of 43 8. And, at 22, he was the youngest Finals MVP since Magic Johnson.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 8. And, at 22, he was the youngest Finals MVP since Magic Johnson. Image 11 of 43 9. He attended San Diego State for two years. He'd leave his house at 5 a.m. every morning to workout before his college classes and it paid off -- he was 2-time first team all-conference and a consensus second team all-American his sophomore year.
Photo: Flickr: Dirkhansen 9. He attended San Diego State for two years. He'd leave his house... Image 12 of 43 10. After missing basketball tryouts due to lack of transportation because his mom was out of town, he lost a spot on the team. He told The New York Times he emailed his coach about the situation but was still unable to play. So, he played football instead his freshman year.
Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, San Antonio Express-News 10. After missing basketball tryouts due to lack of transportation... Image 13 of 43 11. He spent some of his childhood bonding and helping out his father at his car wash.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 11. He spent some of his childhood bonding and helping out his... Image 14 of 43 12. He wants to be in a Spurs jersey for his " whole life " and finish out his career in San Antonio.
Photo: EDWARD A. ORNELAS, SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS-NEWS 12. He wants to be in a Spurs jersey for his " whole life " and... Image 15 of 43 13. He had the team's fifth Larry O'Brien trophy with him in San Diego as part of the tour but it spent two of the three days of the trip in his condo because his devotion to his three-a-day workouts kept him occupied.
"I don't have time to do anything with it," he told the San Diego Union Tribune . "I'm just a low-key guy. I'm just happy we won it. I don't even care about the trophy. The title matters most."
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 13. He had the team's fifth Larry O'Brien trophy with him in San... Image 16 of 43 14. Months before being drafted, he was focused on his college career over raking in millions. "My family doesn't need the money right now. We're not starving, hungry, living poor. It will be nice to have a lot of money, but I think my family could hold out for two more years if I play through my senior year," he told The New York Times.
Photo: 2011 Getty Images 14. Months before being drafted, he was focused on his college... Image 17 of 43 15. He was originally drafter by the Indiana Pacers. Thankfully, he found out he had been traded to the Spurs five minutes after shaking hands with David Stern in a Pacers hat, because that just doesn't look right.
Photo: 2011 Getty Images 15. He was originally drafter by the Indiana Pacers. Thankfully, he... Image 18 of 43 16. According to the San Diego Union Tribune, he shared a two-story home with his mom during his first three years in San Antonio.
"The idea was that he was 19 when he was drafted after his sophomore year at SDSU, and he wanted to ensure her baby has to worry about only playing basketball, not what he was eating for dinner or how much detergent to pour in the washing machine," the Union Tribune reported.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 16. According to the San Diego Union Tribune, he shared a two-story... Image 19 of 43 17. He didn't think the bobbleheads given out to fans at the AT&T Center to celebrate his return from a hand injury looked like him. “It’s all right. It doesn’t look like me. I just take it for what it is," he said.
Photo: Dan McCarney 17. He didn't think the bobbleheads given out to fans at the AT&T... Image 20 of 43 18. He has a soft, funny spot for young fans, obviously.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 18. He has a soft, funny spot for young fans, obviously. Image 21 of 43 19. His skills are so impressive, coaches of other teams and broadcasters in rival cities are fans of him. Back when the New Orleans Pelicans were the Hornets, he made a dunk that made a sports analyst in the Big Easy call him "Kawow."
19. His skills are so impressive, coaches of other teams and... Image 22 of 43 20. Despite what everyone else may think, he told the San Antonio Express-News in 2012 he does smile.
"You might see it," Leonard said. "If we win the championship." Two years later, he made good on his promise.
Photo: Tony Gutierrez /Associated Press 20. Despite what everyone else may think, he told the San Antonio... Image 23 of 43 21. Head coach Gregg Popovich and the Big Three have called Leonard the future of the Spurs. If true, the team is in qualified, big hands that measure 11.25" wide.
Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, San Antonio Express-News 21. Head coach Gregg Popovich and the Big Three have called Leonard... Image 24 of 43 22. Leonard was named to the NBA all-Rookie first team in 2012, and to the NBA all-defense second team in 2014.
Photo: Kin Man Hui, San Antonio Express-News 22. Leonard was named to the NBA all-Rookie first team in 2012, and... Image 25 of 43 24. Eight of the 14 players drafted ahead of him in 2011 have not made it to the playoffs once. Leonard has made the playoffs every year of his career.

Photo: San Antonio Express-News San Antonio Spurs' Kawhi Leonard tries to block a shot by Miami... Image 43 of 43 For Kawhi Leonard, the goal is more championships nothing more 1 / 43 Back to Gallery It seems like yesterday when Kawhi Leonard hoisted the 2014 NBA Finals MVP award after helping the Spurs win their fifth championship.
Almost a year later, Leonard was in the spotlight again, being named the 2014-15 NBA Defensive Player of the Year. One would think Leonard, like other NBA stars around the league, would desire more recognition.
Making the All-Star team? First Team selection? League MVP?
RELATED: Work never stops for Spurs' new $94 million man
"I just want (another) one of those up there," Leonard said, referring to one of the championship banners hanging from the Spurs' practice facility.
Leonard, 24, has little concern with individual accolades.
"In 2014 I wasn't an All-Star or Defensive Player of the Year," Leonard told the Express-News. "If I can get back and win a championship, that's what I'm trying to do."
Spurs coach Gregg Popovich wasn't surprised Leonard's motivation stems from pursuing a championship.
"That sounds like him," Popovich said. " ... He really is more interested in winning than he is with (individual awards). He's a really selfless kind of guy. ... It's not about him in any way, shape, or form. It's always been about the group."
It's this type of attitude that supports the notion Popovich will be around for a few years after the Big Three dismantle. With Leonard, and now LaMarcus Aldridge added to the mix, Popovich doesn't worry about character issues, just basketball.
"I've always said I've been fortunate with the guys I've had come through here," said Popovich. "My job is pretty easy when people have that character and you don't have to convince them to get over themselves, convince them to be happy for their teammate's success, or to feel responsible to each other. (Leonard) already feels all that. He understands it when we talk about it. It makes it easier to have a team that enjoys playing together."
RELATED: Spurs headline ESPN's Ultimate Standings
But who could doubt Leonard if he did have MVP aspirations, or if making an All-Star team was a goal?
"I'm not one of the guys in the league for the fame," Leonard said. "I'm here so I can take of my family, my mom, my friends and take care of myself. I love the game of basketball and as long as I can do that, keep playing and try to get some more championships with the organization, I'll be happy. I don't care about winning an MVP – the MVP doesn't mean you're the best player in the league."
Asked if that attitude comes from any of the conversations with Michael Jordan, whose brand he's signed to, Leonard said: "It (comes from myself). When I was little ... I was just trying to help my team win championships (in high school and college). I wasn't really a guy that wanted to be the MVP. I was just trying to standout for myself."
The attitude is there, and now it could be time to see Leonard utilized on both ends of the court more frequently. His defensive abilities are well-known, but for the past few years the talk is how the Spurs will incorporate Leonard more on the offensive end.
There were a few sneak previews last season. Remember that season-high 11-game winning streak? Leonard led the Spurs in scoring four times during that span, averaging 19.2 points, 6.1 rebounds, 2.1 steals and shot 56.1 percent from the field (45.2 percent from three). Add to that the fact the Spurs were 19-3 when Leonard scored 20 or more points.
When discussing the plan to get Leonard more involved on offense, Popovich killed the notion that Leonard will be the centerpiece, reminding of the "equal opportunity" system, but did explain how the transition to use Leonard more is in progress.
"You have certain guys you go to," Popovich said. "Manu (Ginobili), Tony (Parker), and Tim (Duncan) were the three guys for most of their career. It shifted a little bit – it shifted from Timmy to Manu and Tony. You don't take it away from the former (completely), but now it shifts a little bit towards Kawhi, a little bit towards LaMarcus. But you can't forget about Timmy, Manu and Tony."
One area the Spurs may use Leonard more this season is in the post. Leonard has worked on that area of his game last few years, while still learning to become a perimeter threat. He took a career-high 93 shots last season from the right side of the post/paint area (shot 44.1 percent). With Aldridge – usually working the left block – and now Leonard, the Spurs' post game could be stronger than in recent years.
Said Popovich: "We're going to put (Leonard) in the post more and more, so he's got to learn what his go-to moves are, what he feels comfortable with and the type of (defenders) that are going to come after him (while in the post). Just like they came after Timmy early in his career, they'll go after Kawhi. They're not going to let him go one-on-one down there. He's got to figure out how to adjust, how to take advantage of that, and basically learn how to be a quarterback. That's what he's doing."
It all sounds great: Leonard hungry for more titles, Popovich hoping to make him more of a two-way player, all of it. But time will tell how it unfolds.
Make no mistake, though, Leonard is more motivated than ever to help the Spurs coordinate another championship run, while at the same time becoming a more dominant player.
"That drive is back this year," said Leonard. "We got a lot of good pieces and we're a little bit better than we were last year talent-wise. We just have to build our team chemistry back in order to get to that (championship level)."
jyoung@express-news.net
Twitter: @Jabari_Young
